large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: Clifford the Big Red Dog

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children with a song, and introduce vocabulary (height, habits).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, What are some good things about having a dog?
Read for enjoyment and comparing sizes.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Measure, describe and compare height and length of objects using like units and words like small, big, short, tall, and long; Compare and order up to 5 objects by a measurable attribute.
Reframe the narrative in order to persist and self-motivate.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to compare different sizes of objects and people.
Help children organize and compare people and items by height.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we help animals stay healthy?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What sizes of things do you see or hear about?
Can you pretend to be a dog? What do you do?
Which objects are taller? Which are shorter?
Can you write about what it would be like to have a dog?
What can you draw that is tall?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of dog?
What are you building? How can you make it taller?

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: Clifford the Big Red Dog

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder reframe the narrative and introduce vocabulary (positive).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Clifford the Big Red Dog.
Read closely to notice the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Measure, describe and compare height and length of objects using like units and words like small, big, short, tall, and long; Compare and order up to 5 objects by a measurable attribute.
Reframe the narrative in order to persist and self-motivate.
Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs.
Compose an informative text.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to construct different-sized towers.
Help children to compare heights and widths of objects.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we help animals stay healthy?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Does anyone feel positive in this book? How do they show it?
Can you act like you are very tall? Very small?
Which are the biggest objects? Which are the smallest?
Can you write about how Emily Elizabeth feels about Clifford?
Can you make one bigger thing and one smaller thing?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of Clifford? What other sounds do you hear?
Can you build a home for a dog?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Clifford the Big Red Dog by Norman Bridwell. Copyright © 1963, 1985 by Norman Bridwell. Published by Scholastic Inc. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: Clifford the Big Red Dog

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to introduce subitizing, play a clapping game, and introduce vocabulary (heavy, light).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Clifford the Big Red Dog and asking the guiding question, How does Emily Elizabeth take care of Clifford even though he is so big?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and to review comparing objects and people by size.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Subitize the number of items in a group up to 5.
Describe and compare weight of objects using words like heavy and light; Compare and order up to 5 objects by a measurable attribute.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Describe a situation in a new way in order to empower or motivate.
Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs; Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children pick up objects and find objects that are heavier and lighter.
Invite children to talk about and compare the weight of objects.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we help animals stay healthy?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How can you tell which things are heavy and which things are light in that book?
How could you act to pretend to be a big dog?
Which object is heavier? Which object is lighter? How do you know?
Can you write about how you would take care of a dog?
Why did you make that the size you did?
Can you think of an animal that begins with the letter d?
What materials can you build with that are heavy? What materials can you build with that are light?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Clifford the Big Red Dog by Norman Bridwell. Copyright © 1963, 1985 by Norman Bridwell. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photos © Shutterstock: balls (New Africa), feathers (Potapov Alexander).

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: What Pets Need
Book: Clifford the Big Red Dog

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to play a subitizing game with number cards and introduce vocabulary words (exercise, pets).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts What Pets Need and Clifford the Big Red Dog .
Read interactively, focusing on this week’s question: How can we help animals stay healthy?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Compare and order up to 5 objects by a measurable attribute.
Describe and sort objects by similarities and differences.
Subitize the number of items in a group up to 5.
Try to help others make things better or easier.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to sort pictures of animals by size.
Guide children to sort a collection, like buttons.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we help animals stay healthy?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Is anyone doing any exercise in that book? What kind?
Pretend to be any type of pet. Why did you choose that pet?
What are different ways we can compare the sizes of objects?
Can you write about a kind of pet you would like to have? How would that pet compare to Clifford?
Why did you choose to make that the size it is? How would it change if it were bigger or smaller?
Can you look around the room and find a bigger example of that letter? A smaller one?
How can you make your structure even bigger?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Clifford the Big Red Dog by Norman Bridwell. Copyright © 1963, 1985 by Norman Bridwell. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photos © Rainbow4527/Shutterstock.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: Clifford the Big Red Dog

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to connect to literacy, have children act out different ways of taking care of a pet, and review vocabulary (pet).
Start Story Time by revisiting the book Clifford the Big Red Dog and asking, How would you take care of a pet?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and a focus on measurement and counting.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Measure, describe and compare height and length of objects using like units and words like small, big, short, tall, and long; Describe and compare weight of objects using words like heavy and light.
Subitize the number of items in a group up to 5.
Try to help others make things better or easier.
Use frequently occurring nouns and verbs.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols; Verbally share the meaning of own writing.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to the prompt: What pet would you like to have, how big would it be, and how would you care for it?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we help animals stay healthy?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What kind of book would you like to read next?
Pretend you are choosing a pet. How will you choose one?
This is a small [object]. What is something in the room that is even smaller than it? What is something much larger?
What story can you tell about a made-up pet?
Can you create a big pet that no one has ever seen before?
Make up a name for a new pet. What sound do you hear at the beginning of the word?
What ideas do you have for building a home for your new pet? What materials do you need?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Clifford the Big Red Dog by Norman Bridwell. Copyright © 1963, 1985 by Norman Bridwell. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize and compare heights or lengths of people or objects.
Reframe the narrative in order to persist and self-motivate.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways or knowing the meaning of 3,000 to 4,000 words*, many more than they use.
Recognize and compare heights or lengths of people or objects.
Reframe the narrative in order to persist and self-motivate.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways or knowing the meaning of 3,000 to 4,000 words*, many more than they use.
Write to communicate their ideas for a variety of purposes.
Verbally identify, without counting, the number of objects from 1 to 5.
Informally recognize and compare weights of objects or people.
Reframe the narrative in order to persist and self-motivate.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways or knowing the meaning of 3,000 to 4,000 words*, many more than they use.
Verbally identify, without counting, the number of objects from 1 to 5.
Informally recognize and compare weights of objects or people.
Sort objects that are the same and different into groups and use language to describe how the groups are similar and different.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways or knowing the meaning of 3,000 to 4,000 words*, many more than they use.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Verbally identify, without counting, the number of objects from 1 to 5.
Informally recognize and compare weights of objects or people.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways or knowing the meaning of 3,000 to 4,000 words*, many more than they use.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
